          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <!-- environment -->
     <div class="navhover environmentSwatch" id="hoverEnvironment">

       <div class="display">

        </div>

          RECENT
         </h2>
         <ul>
         </ul>

         <div>

       <!-- Start main content grid -->
       <div class="gridRow mainContentGrid">
        <!-- Content well -->
        <div class="gridColumn six">
         <div class="contentWell">
          <div id="blog-header">
           <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/" style="display:block;width:100%;height:100%;">
            <div class="avatar">
             <img alt="" src="	

http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/wp-content/themes/discoverblog/images/blog_icons/large/plait.png"/>
            </div>
            <div class="words">
             <h1>
              Bad Astronomy
             </h1>
             <p class="credit">
             </p>
            </div>
           </a>
          </div>
          <div class="singlepost">
           <div class="post" id="post-main-4573">
            <div class="entry">
             <div class="navigation">
              <span class="prev">
               
               <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/newsweek-slams-oprah/" rel="prev">
                Newsweek slams Oprah
               </a>
              </span>
              <span class="next">
               <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/astronauts-in-the-bag/" rel="next">
                Astronauts in the bag
               </a>
               
              </span>
             </div>
             <h1 class="post-title single">
              <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/" rel="bookmark" title="Permanent Link to Should vaccines be compulsory?">
               Should vaccines be compulsory?
              </a>
             </h1>
             <div class="meta">
              <span class="meta-date">
               By
               <a href="http://discovermagazine.com/authors?name=Phil+Plait" style="color:#555">
                Phil Plait
               </a>
               | 
		June 3, 2009 11:51 am
              </span>
             </div>
             <div class="shareIcons" style="border-top:1px solid #999;border-bottom:1px solid #999;padding:7px 0 7px 0;margin-bottom:20px;">
              <div class="addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_32x32_style">
               <a class="addthis_button_preferred_1">
               </a>
               <a class="addthis_button_preferred_2">
               </a>
               <a class="addthis_button_preferred_3">
               </a>
               <a class="addthis_button_preferred_4">
               </a>
               <a class="addthis_button_compact">
               </a>
               <a class="addthis_counter addthis_bubble_style">
               </a>
              </div>
             </div>
             <p>
              I was asked in a recent interview if I thought parents should be mandated by law to vaccinate their children.
             </p>
             <p>
              I hesitated, knowing this was a thorny topic. I said I wasnt sure, which was true. But I may be leaning toward a more definite answer now:
              <em>
               yes
              </em>
              .
             </p>
             <p>
              There is a fine line between creating laws that restrict freedoms versus helping others. You dont have the freedom to murder, of course, which is an extreme example. But what about mandatory vaccinations? Should you have the right to not vaccinate your kids?
             </p>
             <p>
              We have seen cases lately  far too many  where ultrareligious parents have not sought medical attention for their children, and those children have been put at extreme risk and even died. I have no problem at all with having a court taking away those kids and giving them the medical attention they need to live. You have a right to believe whatever religion you want, up until that right interferes with the rights of others. And kids have the right to live.
             </p>
             <p>
              You also have the right to believe in the antivaccinations movements nonsense, even when they lie. But that right ends when kids lives are at stake. And in this case, if we dont have enough people vaccinated against diseases like measles, pertussis, and polio, we will see a resurgence of them and kids will die. Its that simple.
              <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/05/04/antivax-kills/" target="_blank">
               We have the evidence
              </a>
              .
             </p>
             <p>
              In the UK,
              <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/8078500.stm" target="_blank">
               the government is weighing compulsory vaccinations
              </a>
              . I dont envy their Herculean task, nor the public outcry theyll have to endure.
              <a href="http://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/?p=513" target="_blank">
               Steve Novella weighs in on this issue on Science Based Medicine
              </a>
              , and as usual he is thoughtful, calm, rational, and makes a persuasive argument.
             </p>
             <p>
              As Steve points out, using fear to get people to vaccinate may not be such a bad idea,
              <em>
               because we
               <strong>
                should
               </strong>
               be scared
              </em>
              . Logic isnt working (as Im sure the comments to this post will verify), so maybe showing parents what happens to their children when they believe people like Jenny McCarthy is the best way to keep kids from dying.
             </p>
             <p>
              And if you still buy into the utter nonsense of the antivax mouthpieces, then I urge you to read
              <a href="http://www.blacktriangle.org/blog/?p=715" target="_blank">
               this heartbreaking article by author Roald Dahl
              </a>
              , whose daughter died of complications from measles four decades ago. Sadly, the only thing thats changed since then is that the number of deaths from preventable diseases is now on the rise, not waning.
             </p>
             <p>
              The bottom line here is that if you dont vaccinate your children, youre taking a big gamble where the stakes are disease and death
              <strong>
               and youre gambling the lives of children everywhere at the same time
              </strong>
              . Compared to the risk of disease, vaccines are overwhelmingly safe.
             </p>
             <div style="clear:both;">
             </div>
             <div class="categories">
              <span class="more-about">
               CATEGORIZED UNDER:
              </span>
              <a href="http://discovermagazine.com/tags/?tag=antiscience">
               Antiscience
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="http://discovermagazine.com/tags/?tag=piece+of+mind">
               Piece of mind
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="http://discovermagazine.com/tags/?tag=science">
               Science
              </a>
             </div>
             <!-- You can start editing here. -->

                   <p>
                    EDIT:  Woot, I beat Todd.
                    <img alt=":)" class="wp-smiley" src="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif"/>
                    My mental health break was just at the right time.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175120">
                      June 3, 2009 at 11:59 am

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175121">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175121">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/3824de4e04594f25ec0a7144f27f5561?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Proudhon
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    The slippery slope argument is pertinent here.  Of course all kids should be vaccinated, but the State should not be the entity that forceably coerces all children to be vaccinated.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Kids shouldnt eat McDonalds or watch 8 hours of TV a day, and while this is NOT the same as what youre suggesting, its a slippery slope from mandating vaccinations to mandating caloric limits (or insert another example here)
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175121">
                      June 3, 2009 at 12:00 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175122">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175122">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/a14e6a1a963fa7126e6a1ef1803557ad?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://antiantivax.jottit.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Todd W.
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Once again, before commenting, please take a read at the site linked by my name or at factsnotfantasy.com/vaccines.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Phil, dont forget the lives of HIV/AIDS patients, transplant recipients, the elderly, those with allergies to vaccine ingredients, and anyone else whose immune systems are susceptible to these diseases.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Im not certain about compulsory vaccination.  If such a thing were to be instated, it would need to be done with careful consideration, and caveats put in place for those who cannot or should not be vaccinated due to pre-existing health conditions.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175123">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175123">

                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/2b60ad03a38d5fc3996d87ad6e4a3baf?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Autumn
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I say that its a clear no, but all religious objections should be ignored, and vaccination should be cumpulsory without a medical reason.  Some people are immuno-compromised, they should certainly not be forced to undergo vaccination, but it is for them and those like them that the idiotic religious exemptions need to be legally expunged.
                    <br/>
                    I think that it is even easy to construct a legal case for ignoring religion in medical cases importatnt to the larger community.  In the case of vaccinations, allowing a religious sect to compromise herd immunity is legally the same as forcing a religious belief onto others in the community.
                    <br/>
                    If I live in a predominately Orthodox Jewish town, the prevailing religious beliefs can not force me not to sell ham.
                   </p>

                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/2178beca365885f4f291a1159bcf708d?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    emote_control
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Look, I hardly think that theyre going to force people to be vaccinated who have legitimate medical reasons for abstaining.  Thats fine.  We dont need to vaccinate that tiny minority in order to achieve herd immunity.  I think its perfectly reasonable to assume that any law mandating vaccination will very carefully take into account the sort of exceptions that a doctor would argue are necessary to protect public health.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Really, those at-risk groups of people stand to gain the most from mandatory vaccination.  Theyre at the greatest risk of death from the actual diseases.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175129">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175129">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/6f7d7c2e2f729def343b34bd088a6369?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://sugarjules.blogspot.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Jules
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I am on the fence here as well.  Here in B.C. it is mandatory if your children are going to attend a public daycare that they are vaccinated (unless the child for medical reason cannot be vaccinated and they need a drs letter to that affect).  And I think that is more than okay.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    @proudhon made the argument about kids and McDs and TV, well guess what.  Here in B.C. it is now mandatory that your child until they graduate school MUST participate in at least 1 hour of physical activity a day.  Some may think that is a great idea but wait.  The schools will be responsible for 15 minutes of that if they are in elementary, 30 minutes of that if they are in Middle School or HS.  The rest of the time falls on the parents.  Again, it is not a choice.  So what does these mean, if you cannot prove that your child participates in at least 1 hr of physical activity a day, the state can intervene and remove your child.  Yes, this is to combat childhood obesity and the first step they did was removal of all junk foods from schools.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    It becomes very scary when the government starts to make how your raise your children mandatory.  Even so I agree with it, maybe a happy medium would be that if you want your child to go to daycare or public school, they need to be vaccinated unless they cannot for religious/medical reasons and the religious one poses a huge loophole but its a constitutional thing.  If not they have to be home schooled, etc
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    There is no easy solution here
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175129">
                      June 3, 2009 at 12:31 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>

                   <p>
                    I think that making all the vaccines mandatory is going along with the flow of the cooperate/medical dogma, which Im afraid the lead commentator is akin to take.  You notice that he discounted the comments below contradicting his view even before they were written.  That is how science and discourse about matters should not take place.  The fact is that science is always uncertain, their are hidden truths inside every set of data.  Take the autism issue.  Even though the data does not show a correlation, it could be that that there are subsets of the population who are susceptable and since they are not identified and lumped in with the rest of the data set, they end up still supporting the null.   However, there are instances when things are clear cut, polio and measles may be candidates for stronger legal sanctions, but the myriad of other vaccines that they wish to inject our kids with almost right when they are born is where parents should have a choice.

                    Individuals who have been vaccinated have plenty to be afraid of from people who havent.                <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175135">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175135">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/aeaa3c94e54de38b5baa7aa9fa8c09a7?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Dan
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Phils bottom line:  ..if you dont vaccinate your children, youre taking a big gamble where the stakes are disease and death and youre gambling the lives of children everywhere at the same time. Compared to the risk of disease, vaccines are overwhelmingly safe.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Phils bottom line way overstates/oversimplifies the case, and does so from a platform based on dismissive anti-religious rhetoric (as if slapping the religious label on the arguement satisfies all concerns) that is ill-informed about the poorly understood and unknown dangers of vaccines.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I am not religious, Phil.  I am a scientist.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Our immune system is a wonderful thing, having evolved over millions of years to protect us from myriads of diseases.  But it has its limitations, too, and sometimes goes haywire, as seen in the many debilitating autoimmune diseases which adversely affect millions of Americans.  Vaccines certainly have their place, but theyre not the answer to everything and can cause problems with our immune systems.  As such, vaccines should NEVER be compulsory.  Rather, fully-informed consent based on proven scientific research is the solution.  The CDCs vaccinate everyone for everything approach is the unfortunately side-effect of their government mandate to eradicate infectious diseases.  This of course ignores the fact that not all diseases are infectious, and that the long-term effects of vaccinations remains poorly understood.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Have vaccines managed to minimize the spread of some infectious diseases and save millions of lives?  Absolutely!  And its a good thing, too!  Are they the answer to everything?  Absolutely not!  And that is a good thing, as well.  Studies have repeatedly shown the best preventative measure against the spread of disease is based on healthy a healthy body fed with a healthy diet and kept in good shape through a variety of regular and frequent exercise.  Beyond that, vaccines can indeed be of good benefit to society as a whole, but they are NOT the end-all, be-all solution to infectious disease and should NOT be made compulsory.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I find it rather disingenuous of you as a scientist to use your platform here to propagate these issues further, given that youre not an immunologist and have little detailed understanding of the scientific, yet non-political details surrouding this issue.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175135">
                      June 3, 2009 at 12:50 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>

               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175136">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175136">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/adff397780b7982a56371acc6f0985e6?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Caleb Jones
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    @amphiox
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Bzzt. Wrong. There is a BIG difference between mandating by law that people strap a safety harness OUTSIDE their body when operating a vehicle and mandating by law that people inject a substance INSIDE their body.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Should people get vaccines? Absolutely yes.  But the government (or anyone else for that matter) has no right to demand you place (consume, inject, etc.) anything into your body.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175136">
                      June 3, 2009 at 12:54 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175137">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175137">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/a14e6a1a963fa7126e6a1ef1803557ad?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://antiantivax.jottit.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Todd W.
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    While I agree that, in principle, mandatory vaccinations would be a good thing, I urge commenters to really think about the issue and not offer a flippant, immediate of course!.  What precedents would such legislation set?  Are there ways in which such legislation could be used in the future to strip away the rights of others?  Could other legislation arise following this which would have unintended consequences?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    What would the penalties be for violating the legislation?  Just exclusion from public schools?  If the goal is to increase overall immunization rates, then what about private schools?  Will there be fines?  If so, how much?
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175137">
                      June 3, 2009 at 12:55 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>

               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175138">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">

                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/18452b8510205f9118300bdc7cd0b72b?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    MC
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Make it mandatory if the child is going to attend public school, and provide incentives to groups like Boy/Girl Scouts to require kids to be vaccinated before they can join up. Basically I think the law should be that any child that is going to be in close contact with anyone outside their immediate family is required to be vaccinated.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    That way the wacko religious fanatics who are opposed to modern medicine and the irrational anti-vaxxers  can keep their kids unvaccinated but also have to protect the public by not letting them out of the house for any significant activity.
                   </p>

                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/9e9fcd83e6dd6bd9e122e48526a4f109?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    RL
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Im going to amend my answer.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I would add that many states, such as the one I live in, do require vaccinations for schools (public and private) and daycare.  There are exceptions for medical conditions and there is also a religious exemption that can be granted and this cant be a fivolous excuse (like I dont believe in vaccinations).  From the regulations:  General philosophical or moral objection to immunization shall not be sufficient for an exemption on religious grounds.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I very much hate aspects of the Nanny State that I live in (were protected from the dangers of undercooked eggs and from the great danger of pumping our own gas), but I will amend my answer above to state that I dont have a real problem with this type of regulation as long as the vaccination list is reasonable.  Not all vaccinations are equal.  I dont think this kind of power belongs directly in the hands of the federal government, though.  At least at the state level, we can have some kind of say.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">

               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175144">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175144">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/6f7d7c2e2f729def343b34bd088a6369?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://sugarjules.blogspot.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Jules
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    @Todd W If it reaches level 6, wouldnt it be too late?  You cannot be vaccinated if you are sick.  At least that is the criteria here.  If you have shown any sign of illness for a period of time before vaccination, you will not be vaccinated.  The incubation period for these diseases vary, so how would one be able to tell who is already carrying the disease but not yet showing symptoms to those who are disease and vaccine free without carrying out a millions of blood tests that will cost millions of dollars where by the time the results come back, the disease is full blown?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    How are they going to herd the people who have not been vaccinated into clinics?  Logistically waiting until level 6 would be a nightmare.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    In this case, it is so very difficult to find the line between respecting individual freedom and protecting the greater good.  Unfortunately, like with many other things, you grant rights and freedoms to one group of people, it impedes the rights and freedoms of another group.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The antivaxx movements scares the living *beep* out of me.  I have Lupus and am allergic to vaccines so have never been vaccinated.  My youngest had adverse reactions to his first two vaccines, so he was never fully vaccinated.  Any time there is an outbreak of the smallest thing, I am not allowed to leave my house.  It is not a nice way to live.  That being said, forcing this upon people I think is too extreme on the other end of the scale.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175147">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175147">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/2bbdc13da1f56ef433bf2c73fe695a65?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Pieter Kok
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Its been mentioned before, but it is worth reiterating: There is a subtlety in the British case that makes the answer to the question posed in the title of this blog post an even more resounding yes: The proposition is to make vaccination compulsory for anyone
                    <i>
                     who is to attend a state-sponsored school
                    </i>
                    . Since there are alternatives to state-sponsored schools, vaccines
                    <i>
                     per se
                    </i>
                    are not made compulsory, and are therefore harder to argue against.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175147">
                      June 3, 2009 at 1:21 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>

                   </p>

                    My children range in age from 35 to 18. I welcomed every new vaccine as it became available. My youngest children didnt have to suffer through chicken pocks. As a parent, I wanted every protection available for my children.

                    If children attend public schools, it is very difficult for a parent to avoid having their children immunized. It should be just as difficult for children that are home schooled. I feel a REAL  MD type doctor should have the final say if a parent want their children to opt out of the system.

                   </p>
                   <p>
                    As usual, thank you for your insightful and thoughtful comments on the issue. So many here are fond of the slippery slope argument. This is one slippery slope that has real potential to be destructive to our society.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    There are other ways to achieve a near-total coverage of the population with vaccines, some of which have been mentioned above. It should be kept in mind that even government enforced, compulsory vaccination will not achieve 100% coverage.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175153">
                      June 3, 2009 at 1:32 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175154">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175154">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/a14e6a1a963fa7126e6a1ef1803557ad?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://antiantivax.jottit.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Todd W.
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    @LT
                   </p>
                   <blockquote>
                    <p>
                     whats the difference, inside or out? Beyond the natural emotional reaction, i mean. something outside can be just as deadly as something inside of your body. If the government can regulate one, it can the other. There isnt any logical difference.
                    </p>
                   </blockquote>
                   <p>
                    Generally speaking, the possible adverse events that could happen with an external device, like seat belts or bike helmets, is relatively limited.  When something is injected into the body, there are numerous ways that it interacts chemically with the body, potentially leading to many more unforeseen reactions, as compared to the external device.  There is a logical difference.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Further, there is a legal precedence that the state does not generally interfere in the practice of medicine, nor with the right of the patient to determine what medical treatments they receive or refuse.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175154">
                      June 3, 2009 at 1:32 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175155">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175155">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/f5610381e6a4d70dc5fa63f2da672469?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    BJN
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Fear is definitely not a sound basis for making decisions. We should be afraid doesnt sound very rational and its very obnoxious after the last two presidential terms where fear was used to get us into all manner of irrational messes. Playing on fear to motivate the uninformed is what the antiscience folks do. If you want to counter that, you have to provide facts and motivate people to enlightened self-interest.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I have no problem with making certain vaccines mandatory, but only when the science and actuarial data demonstrate a significant benefit to the overall population. But lets not legislate based on fear.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Dont be afraid. Be informed.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">

               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175159">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175159">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/ae406f750b70900e5312000b17b64f90?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    anna
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    MMR vaccinations have been compulsory in my school system for a long time. Until there is some cold hard indisputable proof of Jenny McCarthys claims I would say keep them that way.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    HOWEVER. My answer to this question depends on the way in which the legislation is written. If it a specific, well-tested vaccine  Great! If all signs point to safe and no one has any reason to believe well start making a bigger, long-term problem Im fine with it. If this list includes something as poorly tested and shoved through the system as GARDASIL, Id say absolutely definitely not. My problem with making these things across the board mandatory is that I know better than to trust in the altruism of Pharmaceutical companies and Congressmen. And corruption aside, theres the problem of ignorance  just not knowing the harm that a particular new drug can cause because the proper time hasnt been given to researching it.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Since it could be abused or misused, I would like to reserve the right to deny any vaccine that wasnt well documented, tested, and ABSOLUTELY necessary.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    And I think that fear is VERY RARELY (and this case is not one of the exceptions) an appropriate motivational tool. Effective, however it causes people to make emotional rather than rational decisionsAnd when it comes to Science and Health we should all be trying to make rational decisions. Not fear and anxiety based ones.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175159">

                    Another thought, would mandatory vaccination legislation also impose mandatory quarantine for infected individuals and members of their household?
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175163">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175163">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/42686b2b34613e3ac4be7c2b7fb8054a?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://padraic2112.wordpress.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Pat Cahalan
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    No.  No, no, no, no.  Sorry, Phil, but this is one instance where your general science background fails to cover all the edge cases that would occur if you tried to legislate this.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    In the main, this will not work out the way you would want it to.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    There are too many vaccinations, too many exceptions, and too many possible legal loopholes and consequences that I would not want from making this sort of thing mandatory.  Like Todd said, the number of details that would have to be covered make this just not a good venue for the law.  Auditing it alone would be expensive, and those funds would be better served going to actual care and prevention programs.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Certain types of behaviors cannot be well covered (either encouraging them or prohibiting them) by making them legal or illegal.  Writing this law, auditing the process, and so on would be a gargantuan task, largely resulting in lots of money spent for little practical return.  People that dont want to get vaccinations arent going to get them.  And if you think you can mandate them into doing it, you obviously havent spent any time paying attention to this sort of audit/security problem.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I can get a document that will pass scrutiny (from anyone other than a law enforcement officer skilled in forgeries) as a legal state-issued California drivers license in a little less than a day.  Give me a week and I could probably arrange to get one that came directly from the DMV, and that will fool even a police officer trained in forgery detection, because its for all intents and purposes legit.  This isnt because Im a crook, its because Im pretty well read in the security field.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Hundreds of thousands of people in this country have false identification papers; making being unvaccinated illegal isnt going to make anti-vax people get vaccinated, its just going to make them find a forged certificate so that they can enroll their kid in public school.  Now theyre unvaccinated and criminals, how is that better?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Its the flip opposite problem of making abortions illegal, or outlawing private gun ownership, or making recreational drugs illegal; youre not going to stop the bad behavior, and youre going to spend lots and lots and lots of money foolishly.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    In the realm of process-level thinking, audit is always expensive, and its the worst kind of expensive:  completely unproductive expense.  Youre not *doing* anything, youre checking to make sure something is done, and that is done at a cost.  The old security saw is that Security is a tax on the innocent; you do it when you get a *major* benefit from it or you prevent a *very significantly* risky outcome.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Yes, the anti-vax movement has had consequences.  The law is not the right tool to try and correct this erroneous behavior.  Outside a pandemic, making vaccinations mandatory is a big waste of time and money.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175163">
                      June 3, 2009 at 1:55 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>
               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175164">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175164">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/42686b2b34613e3ac4be7c2b7fb8054a?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://padraic2112.wordpress.com" rel="external nofollow">
                     Pat Cahalan
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Let me rephrase one clause from the above: youre not going to stop the bad behavior assumes that I think all those behaviors are bad.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Change that to, youre not going to stop the behavior you want to stop.  My value judgments on private gun ownership, abortion, and drug is arent germane to the point, and I dont want to give a false impression of them anyway
                    <img alt=":)" class="wp-smiley" src="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif"/>
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175165">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175165">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/e4274d39d08607a12624e06dc544bbc0?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Cheyenne
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I (with an unfortunate feeling) would vote no that we shouldnt make vaccination mandatory at this point. I just dont see how the government could enforce it effectively and I think it would open the floodgates to an even nastier battle over vaccination in the public arena (which could lead to an overall lower rate of vaccination).
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Basically, I dont like the idea of the government enforcing it and I dont think it would do a good job of it. I think there should be a combination of incentives and penalties (health insurance premiums, disqualification from attending public schools, government subsidies of vaccination, etc) that could collectively be used to try to increase the rate of vaccination.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Another specific penalty could possibly be that all of the unvaccinated (those without a legitimate medical reason) should be forced to watch all of Pee-Wee Hermans movieswith Quasar.once a year.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175165">
                      June 3, 2009 at 1:59 pm
                     </a>

                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/42686b2b34613e3ac4be7c2b7fb8054a?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>

                  <div class="commenttext">

                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175166">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:00 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175167">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175167">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/8e0831a3171b75f05b782b013bbbc33d?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://mrbillingham.blogsome.com/" rel="external nofollow">
                     Billingham
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Im going to try to split the difference here:
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I think that its perfectly morally acceptable for a government to require its citizens to be vaccinated on principle.  However, I think that under the United States Constitution, it is illegal and unconstitutional. violating the first amendment in religious cases and generally the penumba rights to privacy.  And I dont want to mess with those rights.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    So Id take it in the UK, where the rights are less specific, but in the US, I think its bad news.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175167">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:02 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>

                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/1ba4a58bb1984f1adb7c9e6f8b2fb572?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Pfooti
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I dont normally respond to these things, but Im changing my policy here. I think there should be a simple rule: youre not required to vaccinate your children, but if you want to enter any public space with them, you need to.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    For example, in order to apply to most universities, you need to show up-to-date vaccination records for some important diseases (dormitories can be bad for infectious diseases). So, if you dont want to vax your kids, fine. Just dont plan on bringing them to public school, the shopping mall, or the playground. Done and done.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175173">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175173">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/5f8331ed0bd79b99bde51c0a9ce51ad8?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://twitter.com/joshuwain" rel="external nofollow">
                     Sylvan (David J Rust)
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Phil,
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    You bring up a compelling argument.  I would agree with you under two conditions:
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    1.  The Citizens could be reasonably certain that the government(s) in question were relying upon verifiable scientific research/testing, and,
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    2.  The drugs being used in such mandatory vaccinations were coming from trusted and vetted sources open to scientific peer review free from the current processes we see in the American system of policial lobbying.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    With an eye towards the Bush Presidency (as just one example  there have been plenty of others) science being subverted by politics is not a conspiracy theory:  it is a matter of record.  Whether this would be used for something Orwellian or (as is more likely) graft-oriented, no-bid contracts, it would make me cautious about advocating any mandatory plan of vaccination without freeing it, as much as humanly possible, from what weve observed to be the current excesses of political and corporate corruption.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Concerns over personal rights in exercising religious and philosophical freedoms are valid but, as you say, those end with the freedom of life.  Minors have a right to live, first and foremost.  They can worry about the dispensation of their immortal soul, later.  I dont know of any religion so strict that it doesnt have a safety valve to allow for pennance arising from mistakes or things done beyond the power of parents  which the proposed vaccination program would fall into.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175173">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:11 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>

                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/afe900623b88eb0e844ef4e0d6dd3d80?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Jeff
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    @Jules:  In this case, it is so very difficult to find the line between respecting individual freedom and protecting the greater good. Unfortunately, like with many other things, you grant rights and freedoms to one group of people, it impedes the rights and freedoms of another group.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    This is the eternal human problem probably since Cro Magnon days.  Finding the line was and will always be the human condition.  So I wouldnt be too hard on Phil for taking a position.  Thats what people do.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">

               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175176">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175176">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/94b1c5e4c62aee38f8cbf434799a221d?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    justcorbly
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    @#2 Proudhon &gt;&gt; 
                    <i>
                     The slippery slope argument is pertinent here. Of course all kids should be vaccinated, but the State should not be the entity that forceably coerces all children to be vaccinated.
                    </i>
                    
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    What slippery slope?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Why not the state?  Are you suggesting that another entity exists, or should exist, with the ability to mandate vaccinations for all children?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Are you so ideologically inclined that you believe it is better for children to be stricken  unnecessarily   with potentially fatal ailments solely to avoid seeing the state exercise an authority it already has?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Are you willing to explain to the parents of children who die because vaccinations are not mandatory that it was all done in the name of protecting them from the ravages of Big Government?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    This is not a matter for individual parents to determine for themselves because the children of those parents  parents who do not vaccinate their children  infect the rest of us when they get sick. My right to avoid getting some killer flu trumps my neighbors right to not vaccinate her kids.  She doesnt have the right to spray water dosed with a measles culture on me, so why does she have the right to allow her unvaccinated kid to sneeze on me?
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175176">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:28 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175179">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175179">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://1.gravatar.com/avatar/92a4f4ffb50fce256e9cb5dfb7ef4595?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F1.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    <a class="url" href="http://www.xanga.com/BobRichter" rel="external nofollow">
                     JediBear
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Way ahead of you, Phil. As you may recall, I was endorsing compulsory vaccination on this blog some time ago.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Vaccination isnt a matter of personal choice. Its a matter of public safety, and thus it is within the rights and is further the responsibility of governments to mandate it and to see that mandate carried out.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    How that would need to be done is a matter for scientists and policy-makers, which I am neither, but it needs to be done.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    As to the slippery-slope argument: Your right to swing your fist ends where my nose begins. Thats the classic determination of the extent of personal liberty, and the liberty to forgo vaccination crosses that line. There is no slope here, slippery or otherwise, merely a recognition that the freedom that has traditionally been allowed with regards to vaccination actually impinges in the case of its excersise upon the rights of others.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175179">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:44 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175181">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175181">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/eb3636a34b6ba3cec404d7c968d1791d?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Mike
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I have little patience with slippery-slope arguments.  Because we do A in a given situation does not compel us to do A in all situations which have a passing similarity with the first case.  Often, the slippery-slope argument is advanced in lieu of doing something which actully requires effort: thinking. We were given a brain.  Why would some restrict us from using that brain to draw distinctions?
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175181">
                      June 3, 2009 at 2:53 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </li>

                     The Chemist
                    </a>
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    People are missing the point of E. Allen Blanks statement. I know
                    <a href="http://mychemicaljourney.blogspot.com/2009/06/edgar-allen-wha.html" rel="nofollow">
                     because I wrote it
                    </a>
                    . Hes supposed to be  a
                    <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inedia" rel="nofollow">
                     breatharian
                    </a>
                    and imposing this practice on his child. The point was that if the government forced him to feed or relinquish the child because of a specific and certain risk, no one would bat an eye. Yet if someone places their child at a non-specific risk of disease, suddenly were talking about the parents rights without regard to those of the child. A child has a right to be free from the highly avoidable perils of some diseases.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175189">

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="li-comment-175190">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175190">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/206869bdc153dfc4085bc9fd0725e5bb?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Radwaste
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    Heres a NO.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    1) This plan would be administrated by the people who brought you the Transportation Security Administration.
                    <br/>
                    2) If you advocate compulsory vaccination, please show me how you have determined that the process will NOT adversely affect me. Aside from violating the Constitution (threat to liberty absent due process), a
                    <i>
                     person
                    </i>
                    is genetically unique. Those of you who are going on about seatbelts or helmet laws are engaging in a straw man argument, because restraints and protective gear can be built to perform over a range of physical features when they are apparent. For the slow, genetically unique means that vaccines differ in effect from person to person, just as the severity of viral disease varies. Yes, there are both vaccines and virii that demonstrate similar effects on the bulk of humanity. That does not show that either safety or a test for it exists.
                    <br/>
                    3) As to establishing a slippery slope  the next step, immediately, would be ID implants, for your safety. Clearly, a powerful central government with many people to track will have to have a means of doing so; RFID could prove you were at the scene of a crime, and that clearly benefits all of society. Then, the people in charge of the database can claim anything they want; the individual doesnt have a way to challenge such powers.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    One batch of bad poliomyelitis vaccine crippled and killed more people than antivax-related exposure has, yes, so far. Its production and distribution was approved and expedited by public health authorities. Im sure that was a great comfort to those afflicted.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175190">

                    <i>
                     you
                    </i>
                    (presumably youre an adult, free and clear to make your own decisions). No one is talking about compulsory vaccination for adults but compulsory vaccination for children who are entering the school system.

               <!-- #comment-## -->
               <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="li-comment-175193">
                <div class="commentwrap clearfix">
                 <div class="commentBox clearfix" id="comment-175193">
                  <div class="comment-author vcard">
                   <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-84 photo" height="84" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/67d7c840414336748ef5abcb9eb6b946?s=84&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2F0.gravatar.com%2Favatar%2Fad516503a11cd5ca435acc9bb6523536%3Fs%3D84&amp;r=G" width="84"/>
                   <cite class="fn">
                    Dan I.
                   </cite>
                  </div>
                  <div class="commenttext">
                   <p>
                    I think compulsory vaccines are fine, but I wholeheartedly disagree with those who say no religious exemptions.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    First of all, the amount of people with bona fide religious exemptions is going to be very small, we arent talking about some wacko new-age cult getting exemptions. States actually have lists of religious organizations that are allowed exemptions. The amount of kids not vaccinated for bona fide religious reasons is going to be so small that herd immunity will cover it.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Its also very easy for the non-religious, the atheist, or the not that religious to say No Religious exemptions because I dont feel such people really appreciate how important a religion can be to people.
                   </p>
                   <div class="comment-meta commentmetadata">
                    <span class="commentdate">
                     <a href="http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/badastronomy/2009/06/03/should-vaccines-be-compulsory/#comment-175193">
                      June 3, 2009 at 4:45 pm
                     </a>
                    </span>
                    <span class="reply">
                    </span>
                   </div>
                  </div>
